p.hi: NEW MODULI SPACES OF POINTED CURVES
AND PENCILS OF FLAT CONNECTIONS

body.p: Abstract. It is well known that formal solutions to the Associativity Equations are the same as cyclic algebras over the homology operad (H*â¢(MÂ¯0,n+1))subscriptğ»subscriptÂ¯ğ‘€0ğ‘›1 of the moduli spaces of nğ‘›â€“pointed stable curves of genus zero. In this paper we establish a similar relationship between the pencils of formal flat connections (or solutions to the Commutativity Equations) and homology of a new series LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› of pointed stable curves of genus zero. Whereas MÂ¯0,n+1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘€0ğ‘›1 parametrizes trees of â„™1superscriptâ„™1â€™s with pairwise distinct nonsingular marked points, LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› parametrizes strings of â„™1superscriptâ„™1â€™s stabilized by marked points of two types. The union of all LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘›â€™s forms a semigroup rather than operad, and the role of operadic algebras is taken over by the representations of the appropriately twisted homology algebra of this union.

p.hi: 0. Introduction and plan of the paper

body.p: One of the remarkable basic results in the theory of the Associativity Equations (or Frobenius manifolds) is the fact that their formal solutions are the same as cyclic algebras over the homology operad (H*â¢(MÂ¯0,n+1))subscriptğ»subscriptÂ¯ğ‘€0ğ‘›1 of the moduli spaces of nğ‘›â€“pointed stable curves of genus zero. This connection was discovered by physicists, who observed that the data of both types come from models of topological string theories. Precise mathematical treatment was given in [KM] and [KMK].

In this paper we establish a similar relationship between the pencils of formal flat connections (or solutions to the Commutativity Equations: see 3.1â€“3.2 below) and homology of a new series LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› of pointed stable curves of genus zero. Whereas MÂ¯0,n+1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘€0ğ‘›1 parametrizes trees of â„™1superscriptâ„™1â€™s with pairwise distinct nonsingular marked points, LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› parametrizes strings of â„™1superscriptâ„™1â€™s, and all marked points with exception of two are allowed to coincide (see the precise definitions in 1.1 and 2.1). Moreover, the union of all LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘›â€™s forms a semigroup rather than operad, and the role of operadic algebras is taken over by the representations of the appropriately twisted homology algebra of this union: see precise definitions in 3.3.
This relationship was discovered on a physical level in [Lo1], [Lo2]. Here we give a mathematical treatment of some of the main issues raised in these papers.
This paper is structured as follows.

In Â§1 we introduce the notion of (A,B)ğ´ğµâ€“pointed curves whose combinatorial structure generalizes that of strings of projective lines described above. We then describe a construction of â€œadjoining a generic black pointâ€ which allows us to produce families of such curves and their moduli stacks inductively. This is a simple variation of one of the arguments due to F.Â Knudsen [1].

In Â§2 we define and study the spaces LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› for which we give two complementary constructions. The first one identifies LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› with one of the moduli spaces of pointed curves. The second one exhibits LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› as a wellâ€“known toric manifold associated with the polytope called permutohedron in [Ka2]. These constructions put LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› into two quite different contexts and suggest generalizations in different directions.

As moduli spaces, LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› become components of the extended modular operad which we define and briefly discuss in Â§4. We expect that there exists an appropriate extension of the Gromovâ€“Witten invariants producing algebras over extended operads involving gravitational descendants.

As toric varieties, (LÂ¯n)subscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› form one of the several series related to the generalized flag spaces of classical groups: see [GeSe]. It would be interesting to generalize to other series our constructions.

In this paper we use the toric description in order to prove for LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘›â€™s an analog of Keelâ€™s theorem (Theorem 2.7.1) and its extension (Theorem 2.9), crucial for studying representations of the twisted homology algebra.
This twisted homology algebra H*â¢Tsubscriptğ»ğ‘‡ and its relationship with pencils of formal flat connections are discussed in Â§3, which contains the main result of this paper: Theorem 3.3.1.

Acknowledgement. Yu.Â Manin is grateful to M.Â Kapranov who, after having seen the formula Ï‡â¢(LÂ¯n)=n!ğœ’subscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘›ğ‘›, suggested that LÂ¯nsubscriptÂ¯ğ¿ğ‘› must be the toric variety associated with the permutohedron.

body.p: Proof. Properness and smoothness follow by induction and Knudsenâ€™s local analysis which we already invoked.

The statement about the combinatorial types is proved by induction as well. In fact, if everything is already proved for Cnsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›, then we must look at a geometric fibre Cn,ssubscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘ of Cnsubscriptğ¶ğ‘› and see what happens to it after the blow up described in 1.3. If Î”Î” intersects a smooth point of Cn,ssubscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘ , not coinciding with x0,s,xâˆ,ssubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ , nothing happens, except that we get a new black point on this fibre, and a new tail at the respective vertex of the dual graph. If Î”Î” intersects an intersection point of two neighboring components of Cn,ssubscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘ , then after blowing up these two components become disjoint, and we get a new component intersecting both of them, with a new black point on it. The linear structure of the graph is preserved. Finally, if Î”Î” intersects Cn,ssubscriptğ¶ğ‘›ğ‘ at x0,ssubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘ or xâˆ,ssubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ , then after blowing up we will get a new end component, with x0,ssubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘ , resp. xâˆ,ssubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ and the new black point on it. Thus the new combinatorial types will be linear and indexed by partitions of (n+1)ğ‘›1. To check that all partitions are obtained in this way, it suffices to remark that Î”Î”, being the relative diagonal, can intersect the fibre of a given type at any point.

First, our manifolds would become actual stacks, starting already with LÂ¯1subscriptÂ¯ğ¿1. Second, we would have lost the toric interpretation of these spaces. With our choice, we can simply introduce the involution permuting x0subscriptğ‘¥0 and xâˆsubscriptğ‘¥ as a part of the structure and look how it interacts with other parts.

3.2.3. Flat coordinates and gravitational descendants. One can show that 1â€“forms on Mğ‘€ flat with respect to the dualized first structure connection are closed and therefore locally exact. Their integrals are called deformed flat coordinates. In [Du2], Example 2.3 and Theorem 2.2, B.Â Dubrovin gives explicit formal series in Î»ğœ† (zğ‘§ in his notation) for suitably normalized deformed flat coordinates. This is important because apriori only modified correlators are defined for an arbitrary Cohomological Field Theory in the sense of [KM1], which is not necessarily quantum cohomology of a manifold.

4.3.1. Combinatorial types of fibers. Let us remind that combinatorial types of classical (semi)stable curves with (only white) points labeled by a finite set Ağ´ are isomorphism classes of graphs, whose vertices are labeled by â€œgeneraâ€ gâ‰¥0ğ‘”0 and tails are bijectively labeled by elements of Ağ´. Stability means that vertices of genus 0 bound â‰¥3absent3 flags, and vertices of genus 1 bound â‰¥1absent1 flags. Graphs can have edges with only one vertex, that is, simple loops. Appendix. Proof of the Technical Lemma

We break the proof into several steps whose content is indicated in the title of the corresponding subsection. An advice for the reader who might care to check the details: the most daunting task is to convince oneself that none of the alternatives has been inadvertently omitted.
